summary: This document appears to be a note or email from a staff member (likely a corrections officer or counselor) describing a visit with inmate Jeffrey Epstein in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). The staff member reports that Epstein was in good mental state, denied suicidal thoughts, made various requests, and was preparing to meet with his attorneys. The document is significant as it provides a snapshot of Epstein's condition and circumstances while in custody shortly before his death. This document is a Federal Bureau of Prisons 24-hour death report and the official autopsy report for Jeffrey Epstein. It details the timeline of his suicide watch, his death by hanging in his cell at MCC New York on August 10, 2019, and the subsequent medical response and autopsy findings, which officially ruled the manner of death as suicide.

events.title: SHU Visit with Epstein
events.description: A staff member visited inmate Jeffrey Epstein in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) on a Thursday. Epstein was reported to be in good mental state, denied suicidal thoughts, made various requests (e.g., social calls without speaker phone, retrieval of a book), and was preparing to meet with his attorneys.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Suicide Watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on Suicide Watch for 31 hours and 5 minutes due to an abrasion on his neck.

events.title: Epstein Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was taken off Suicide Watch and placed on Psychological Observation.

events.title: Epstein Placed in SHU with Cellmate
events.description: Epstein was removed from Psychological Observation and placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) where he was housed with a cellmate.

events.title: Final Psychology Assessment
events.description: Epstein was seen by Psychology Services and denied suicidal ideation, intention, or plan.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: At 6:33 a.m., SHU staff found Epstein unresponsive in his cell. CPR was initiated, EMS was called, and he was transported to New York Presbyterian Lower Manhattan Hospital where he was pronounced dead at 7:36 a.m.

events.title: Autopsy Performed
events.description: An autopsy was performed on Jeffrey Epstein's body by Medical Examiner Kristin Roman, commencing at 9:21 AM.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was housed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the time of the visit.
Epstein denied any suicidal thoughts or intentions to the staff member during the visit.
Epstein was making specific requests, including social calls without a speaker phone and retrieval of a book left in a suicide watch area.
Epstein was preparing to meet with his attorneys to work on his legal situation.
The staff member observed no signs of distress, depression, or anxiety in Epstein during the visit.
The official cause and manner of Jeffrey Epstein's death, as determined by the NYC Medical Examiner's Office, was 'Hanging' and 'Suicide (Hanged Self).'
Epstein was found unresponsive in his Special Housing Unit (SHU) cell at MCC New York on the morning of August 10, 2019, and was pronounced dead at a hospital at 7:36 a.m.
The autopsy revealed a ligature furrow on the neck, fractures of the thyroid cartilage and hyoid bone, and petechial hemorrhages, all consistent with hanging.
Epstein had been on suicide watch from July 23-24, 2019, after being found with an abrasion on his neck, but was removed and placed in the SHU with a cellmate by July 30.
Just two days before his death, on August 8, 2019, Epstein was assessed by Psychology Services and denied any suicidal ideation, intention, or plan.
